CatDescriptText: Mr. Frank Greenlee, salesman, North Side and Mr. Paul Rosenberger, postal worker, Brookline, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 10, 1962, pg. 7 with question: "Who had the more dangerous assignment--Lindbergh or Glenn?" Mr. Frank Greenlee's answer reads: "In a way, Lindberg was the braver because his came during the infancy of aviation.  He didn't have the facilities to pull him back whereas Glenn has such facilities."  Mr. Paul Rosenberger's answer reads: "I think Lindberg, because he faced more of the unknown than Glenn did.  When Lindberg went, it was his own thoughts and idea that he could make it.  In other words, everything depended on him; whereas Glenn had scores of scientists who could have pulled him back and who decided when he was going to make the flight."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Frank Greenlee wearing corduroy jacket with plaid lining and cap with omega symbol, standing in front of row of stores, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of postman Paul Rosenberger, standing across from Sherwin Williams and Brass Rail Restaurant, Smithfield Street, Downtown
